message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest hyperthyroidism, which can cause atrial fibrillation and hypertension. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can control the heart rate and symptoms of hyperthyroidism. Propylthiouracil and Methimazole are used to treat hyperthyroidism but won't help control the heart rate. Warfarin is not indicated unless there is evidence of thromboembolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including palpitations, tremor, digital swelling, warm extremities, and retraction of right upper eyelid, suggest hyperthyroidism. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can help manage the symptoms while further evaluation for hyperthyroidism is being done. Propylthiouracil and Methimazole are treatments for hyperthyroidism, while Warfarin is used for anticoagulation and is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of hyperthyroidism, which can cause palpitations, tremors, and digital swelling. The retraction of the right upper eyelid is a sign of Graves' disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can control the heart rate and improve symptoms. It is the most appropriate initial management step. Propylthiouracil and methimazole are antithyroid drugs that will reduce the production of thyroid hormone, but they take time to work and are not the initial treatment choice. Warfarin is an anticoagulant and would not be indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hyperthyroidism, and among the options, the best initial step is to prescribe Propranolol to control the palpitations and tremors. Propylthiouracil and Methimazole are used to decrease thyroid hormone levels, and Warfarin is used to prevent blood clots, which are not necessary in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hyperthyroidism and the tremor, digital swelling, warm extremities, and retraction of the upper eyelid suggest Graves disease. The irregular pulse and blood pressure indicate atrial fibrillation, making beta-blockers like propranolol the most appropriate next step for managing the symptoms. Propylthiouracil and Methimazole are used to treat hyperthyroidism, while Warfarin is used to prevent blood clots.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hyperthyroidism, specifically Graves’ disease. The fine tremor and digital swelling can also indicate hyperthyroidism. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can help with the palpitations and tremors associated with hyperthyroidism. Propylthiouracil and Methimazole are used to treat hyperthyroidism by blocking the production of hormones. Warfarin is an anticoagulant medication and is not appropriate in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest hyperthyroidism, specifically Graves' disease. A fine tremor, digital swelling, and heat intolerance are classic symptoms. The retraction of the right upper eyelid is also known as a lid-lag and is a sign of thyroid eye disease. The irregularly irregular pulse suggests atrial fibrillation, which can occur in patients with hyperthyroidism. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can control symptoms of hyperthyroidism, including palpitations and tremors. Propylthiouracil and Methimazole are used to treat hyperthyroidism, but they take longer to work and are used more for long-term management rather than acute control of symptoms. Warfarin is not indicated in this case as there is no indication of a thrombotic event or atrial fibrillation with a high risk of embolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest hyperthyroidism, specifically Graves' disease. Propranolol can help control the palpitations and tremor. Methimazole or propylthiouracil can be used for long-term management of hyperthyroidism, but they won't provide immediate symptom relief. Warfarin is not indicated for this patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hyperthyroidism, specifically Graves' disease due to the presence of exophthalmos and lid lag. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can help control the heart rate and palpitations. Propylthiouracil and Methimazole are anti-thyroid medications that can be used to treat hyperthyroidism, but they take longer to work. Warfarin is an anticoagulant and not appropriate for this patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest hyperthyroidism, and the fine tremor is a classic sign of hyperthyroidism. The irregularly irregular pulse and digital swelling suggest atrial fibrillation, which is a complication of hyperthyroidism. Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can control the heart rate and palpitations associated with hyperthyroidism. Propylthiouracil and methimazole are anti-thyroid medications, and warfarin is used for anticoagulation, which is not indicated in this case.
